awd_abstract_narration:
Cryptography is one of the foundational elements of cybersecurity.  Crypto is a top-tier, peer-reviewed, highly selective conference in cryptography, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to Crypto range from theoretical foundation of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes.

The requested funds will be used to support student travel awards, and underrepresented groups will be especially encouraged to apply. Students who otherwise would not be able to attend will be given the chance to deepen their knowledge modern cryptography research and meet researchers and other students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Modern cryptography studies secure communication and computation in the presence of potentially adversarial parties. The longest running and most prominent academic conference on modern cryptography, Crypto is sponsored by the International Association of Cryptologic Research (IACR), which also sponsors Eurocrypt, Asiacrypt, a number of more specialized conferences, and the Journal of Cryptology. The first Crypto was held in 1981 at UC Santa Barbara, and since then Crypto has been IACR’s flagship conference every year in the same location, attracting researchers in the field of cryptology from all over the world.

The scope of research papers accepted to Crypto range from theoretical foundations to cryptanalysis to applications. In recent years attendance at Crypto has gone up, and even the first post-COVID lockdown conference held last year had over 400 participants.

Crypto’23 and its affiliated workshops were held in Santa Barbara, CA, August 19-24, 2023.

This award made is possible for student authors and several other student cryptographers to attend Crypto 2024.  Specifically, twenty-two Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral fellow were awarded stipends covering the costs of attending the conference.  In addition to attending the conference talks and presenting their own work either as part of the main program or as park of the rump session, student attendees participated in mentoring sessions with more senior cryptography researchers.


Last Modified: 07/15/2024
Modified by: Anna A Lysyanskaya
